data.title: Friends rally around disabled New Westminster Hyacks coach Ryan Leslie
data.text:
Article content

The “gentle giant” of the Hyacks Football program has given a big part of his life to the community as a youth football coach and a leader.

“I had been under general anesthetic and very quickly they started asking me to move my feet and my arms, and I suddenly realize I can’t feel anything,” said Leslie, a father to two young boys. “It was quite disturbing, but I didn’t know if that was a known thing that could happen.”

It was not expected, and now all signs point to a lengthy and probably modest recovery.

Leslie’s most immediate goal is to regain the use of his arms and hands, which would allow him to continue working as a manager of software development for Amazon.

“It will be months before I can expect even a small amount of progress,” he said. “But if I can get some function back in my hands, I’ll be a happy camper.”

Friends of “Coach Ryan” have created a GoFundMe campaign to help Leslie and his family deal with expenses, especially retrofits to the family home, according to friend Farhan Lalji, a sports reporter for TSN.

“Now comes the rest of his life, so he’ll need to modify the house and modify a vehicle, and go through all those expenses,” said Lalji. “He has good (insurance) coverage, but it doesn’t cover everything, and there’s going to be a lot of changes needed.”

Leslie’s GoFundMe campaign exceeded its goal of $15,000 in less than two days.

“It’s been amazing how many people have reached out and want to help,” said Leslie. “I have no idea what I’m going to need, but I will make sure that money gets into the right hands.”

The former UBC Thunderbird player entered hospital on Friday, April 6, to have surgery on an infection in his knee, but a second infection in his foot led doctors to believe Leslie had a larger problem.

“An MRI showed an infection next to his spine, and by Saturday morning this is an emergency situation,” said his wife, Amy. “They got him into surgery really quickly and the surgeon said it shouldn’t be a problem. I wasn’t concerned at all.”

But during surgery, he suffered a sudden drop in blood pressure. When Leslie regained consciousness, he couldn’t feel his legs.

“The doctors were kind of freaking out,” said Amy. “The brutal part is that we still haven’t got a clear answer as to what caused the paralysis.”

The combination of Ryan’s infection, diabetes and the drop in blood pressure may have cut off blood flow to his spine.

“When someone is in a car crash, you think maybe they could be paralyzed, but when it happens like this, it’s just a shocker,” said Amy. “There’s a chance he regains sensation, but he may not.”

Leslie’s parents flew in from Saskatchewan last week to lend their support. Amy’s parents arrived on the weekend to help out, so she can spend more time at the hospital.

Four years ago, Ryan, Amy and their children, Liam, 9, and Casey, 7, moved to Bellevue, Wash.

Liam played his first season of tackle football last year, coached by his dad.

“He really enjoyed it,” said Leslie. “What I love about football is you don’t have to be the best athlete on the field to find success and contribute to the team and enjoy that team experience.”

Leslie was getting ready to serve as president of Seahawks Junior Football in Bellevue for the coming season, but now plans to step down.

He always gravitated to positions of leadership and his impact on the kids he coached in B.C. is incalculable, said Lalji, who visited Leslie in hospital this past weekend.

“Coaching is such a simple thing to do to help young people build confidence,” said Leslie. “It’s amazing how learning a skill and learning discipline becomes a layer that leads to other achievements. It can really be life-changing.”

It was Leslie and Lalji who resurrected the New Westminster Hyacks youth and high school football programs in 2003 after the organization collapsed in the 1970s.

“Ryan coached more than 1,000 kids over the years, and our youth program had unprecedented growth when he was our president,” he said. “He’s a gentle giant, a big guy, but he has a really disarming way about him. He can work with kids of all ages.”

As an administrator, Leslie was highly organized and was able to leverage his professional analytical and information technology skills to keep the organization running smoothly.

“He coached with me when we started up the Hyacks and then he coached on the high school side of the program until 2006,” said Lalji. “Then he ran our youth program until 2014. He was heavily involved.”

Leslie also served on the board of the Vancouver Mainland Football League.

“Ryan has a lot of ties to the community in this province,” said Lalji. “I have calls coming in from all over, from people who want to help him.”

Leslie created a legacy of deep commitment in the Hyack Football organization, said Hyacks atom team coach Bill McDonnell.

“Ryan led by example,” he said. “He would be helping out in practices at every level, he would help coach at the flag level, the atom tackle, the pew wee tackle, and then be there for high school practices.”

Leslie left big shoes to fill when he left for Washington, but the coaches really stepped up based on the example he had set, McDonnell said.

Even after he had been gone for several years, Leslie still made trips back to B.C. to run football clinics.

“This year, the senior team made it to the championship game, and there he is, in the stands,” he said.
